subtitle: chapter nine the eighth pillar
self-reliance every young man ought to
read Emerson's essay on self-reliance it
is the manliest most virile essay that
was ever penned it is calculated to cure
like those two mental maladies common
too young namely self deprecation and
self conceit it is almost assured to
reveal to the prig the smallness and
emptiness of his vanity as it is to show
the bashful man the weakness and an
effectual 'ti of as dividends it is a
new revelation of manly dignity as much
a revelation as any that was vouchsafed
to ancient seer and prophet and perhaps
a more practical eminently suited to
this mechanic's age coming as it does
from a modern prophet of new type and
called in a new race and its chief merit
is its powerful tonic quality let not
self-reliant be confounded with self
conceit first high and excellent as the
one just so low and worthless as the
other there cannot be anything mean in
self-reliance while in self conceit
there cannot be anything great the man

thought ignorant but confidently puts

conceit an honest confession of

independent action he needs that

become a new example instead of the
slavish follower
of an old one as for ridicule he who is
hurt by it is no man the chefs or
mockery and sarcasm cannot pierce the
strong armor of the self-reliant man
they cannot reach the invincible citadel
of his honest heart to sting or wound
him the sharp arrows of irony may rain
upon him but he laughs as they are
deflected by the strong breastplate of
his confidence and fall harmless about
him trust thyself says Emerson every
heart vibrates to that iron string
throughout the ages men have so far

who has that strong metal which enables

worth it is true that the candidate for

in list
he must not fear for his reputation or

he must learn to act and live as

sooner or later all men will turn or

it is they among my disciples who shall

we may both draw light from another and

what is the inner light of the Quakers

upon his own limbs men pray to God to

man's chief trouble is a mistrust of
himself so that the self trusting man
becomes a rare and singular spectacle if
a man looked upon himself as a worm what
can come out of him but an ineffectual
wriggling truly he that humbleth shall

and rely upon that which is of any worth
a man is only debased when he bases
himself he is exalted when he lives an
exalted life why should a man with
ceaseless iterations draw attention to
his fallen nature there is a false

vice if one has fallen it is that he may
rise and be wiser for it if a man falls

call upon every passerby to mark his
fallen state he gets up and goes on his

fallen into the ditch of Vice let him

wherein a man's influence and prosperity

even a measure of self-reliance and to
the teacher whether secular or religious
to organizers managers overseers and in
all positions of control and command it
is an indispensable equipment the four
grand qualities of self-reliance our
decision
steadfastness dignity and independence
decision makes a man strong the weir is
the weakling a man who is to play a
speaking part however small in the drama
of life must be decisive and know what
he is about whatever he doubts he must
not doubt his power to act he must know
his part in life and put all his energy
into it he must have some solid ground
of knowledge from which to work and
stand securely on that it may be only
the price and quality of stock but he
must know his work thoroughly and know
that he knows it he must be ready at any
time to answer for himself when his duty
is impugned he should be so well
grounded upon his particular practice as
not to be affected with hesitation on
any point or in any emergence it is a
true saying that the man that hesitates
is lost
no one believes in him who does not
believe in himself who doubts halts and
wavers and cannot extricate himself from
the tangled threads of two courses who
would deal with a tradesman who did not
know the price of his own goods or was
not sure where to find them a man must
know his business if he does not know
his own who shall instruct him
he must be able to give a good report of
the truth that is in him must have that
touch which only skill and knowledge can
impart certainty is a great element in
self-reliance to have weight a man must

as a communication of truth he must
speak with authority and not as ascribes
he must master something and know that
he has mastered it so as to deal with it
lucidly and understandingly in the way
of a master and not to remain always an
apprentice indecision is a
disintegrating factor a minute's
faltering may turn back the current to
success men who are afraid to decide
quickly for fear of making a mistake
nearly always make a mistake when they
do act the quickest in thought and
action are less liable to blunder and it
is better to act with decision and make
a mistake than to act with indecision
and make a mistake for in the former
case there is but error but in the
latter weakness is added to error a man
should be decided always both what he
knows and what he does not know he
should be as ready to say no as yes as
quick to acknowledge his ignorance as to
impart his knowledge if he stands upon
fact and acts from the simple truth he
will find no room for halting between
two opinions make up your mind quickly

mind that is already made up and
indecision will be instinctive and
spontaneous steadfastness arises in the

belittle it is neither necessary nor

all vows the man without fixed principle

the unsteady mind the mind that is not

while it is a rock of strength to the

self-respecting but that he graciously
treats all others would do esteem pride
it loves itself and treats those beneath
it with supercilious contempt for love
of self and contempt for others are
always found together in equal degrees
so that the greater the self-love the
greater the arrogance true dignity
arises not from self love but from
self-sacrifice that is from unbiased
adherence to a fixed central principle
the dignity of the judge arises from the
fact that in the performance of his duty
he sets aside all personal consideration
and stands solely upon the law his
little personality and permanent and
fleeting becomes nothing while the law
enduring and majestic becomes all should
a judge in deciding a case forget the
law and fall into personal
feeling prejudice his dignity would be
gone so with the man of stately purity

law and not upon personal feeling for
immediately a man gives way to passion
he is sacrificed dignity and takes his

unwise and uncontrolled every man will
